A Ballad of Cumberland, 1319. King Edward sat in York's fair town, His face for wrath was grey, âI gave De Harcla trust and guard Of all my Northern Marches' ward: And do ye say He doth betray His fealty to my crown?â Oh cruel are the tongues that call Dishonour into sight, But crueller the hearts whose greed Will dare defame an honest deed, And out of spite, Accuse the right, And turn true love to gall. What boots it that De Harcla's dread Kept Lions from the gate, That all the Bruce's might and wile Could work no woe against Carlisle, The stone of hate For proud estate Hath fallen upon his head. What boots it for eleven days He mocked the Scottish ring, With arrow flight from wall and towers, With springald shot, and quarrel-showers, With stone and sling, For crown and king He wrought his deed of praise. Lord Lucy at the King's command To Carlisle town hath hied, Hath gotten him daring comrades three, Hugh Lowther, Hugh of Moriceby, And at their side, To be for guide, Denton of Cumberland. These gallant Lords each cloked his arm And through the gates in gloom Paffed on, spake fair the seneschalâ Low firelight flickered in the Hallâ Thence to the room Of Harcla's doom Sped swift without alarm. De Harcla at his table sate A-writing to his friendâ âDear friend do right and dare the worstâ In at those words, the gallants burst,â âDraw and defend!â They cried, âor bend, False knave to King and State!â Then up he rose that haughty Earl And faced the gallants three, âMy hands are white, my heart is pure, And for my King I dare endure Pay honour's fee At Harribee With life's most precious pearl.â No last farewell for squire and dame, No kiss from sire and lord, To close the gates a varlet sprang, A shout thro' all the castle rang, Sir Richard's sword It quenched that word, Four entered, five outcame. To boot and saddle, saddle and horse, Dark streets be good for flight! Beyond the city walls they ride With armÃ¨d men on either side, All through the night Till morning light For York they sped their course. The judge he sat in robes of red, The Earl De Harcla stood As silent as a man of stone, While those accusers one by one Athirst for blood, âBy the Holy Roodâ Heaped hate upon his head. But when of The castle or home-farm, which adjoined the sauceries. âBattail-Holmeâ they spake And that The salceriesâlat. salicetaâcalled so from the willow-bedsâthe castle sauceries of to-day. fair willowy mead Wherein he walked and wooed his dame, Whereon he brought the Bruce to shame, I saw indeed The bright tear speed, His body seemed to quake. They hewed the spurs from off his heel, They tore his plumes apart, Above his head they brake his swordâ No knightlier e'er was grasped by lord, He felt no smart Of flesh, his heart What could it do but feel. His tabard off they plucked amain, His hood, his coat of arms, Despitefully they did unslip The girdle from De Harcla's hipâ The belt whose charms In war's alarms Was never girthed in vain. Lord Lucy quoth, âSo treat we sire All traitors to the King, Whose will is that the people see Their great Earl hanged at Harribee, And whiles you swing Shall fierce hands fling Your heart into a fire. âYour head on London Bridge shall stare, Your limbs once true and brave Shall quartered be, and up and down Go, carrion cast from town to town, âNo English grave Can hold a knaveâ The crows shall pick them bare.â Then spake the Earl, âI have no sears, No grace I seek to find, For well I know who dares the right Is never âdead-man out-of-sight,â But in the mind Of all his kind His life lives on for years. âTake spur and helm, take robe and hood, Break sword above my head, My knightlihood no hands can take, My sword of spirit none can break, When I am dead It shall be read The Earl was true and good. âAnd if mine head on spike be thrust In sight of London Town, It shall not blench for shame to say, âThis mortal went a mortal's way True to his own, His king and crown, Hate smote him to the dust.ââ To Harribee the Earl they bore, Oh bitter was the cry, But when they tore his true heart out To Heaven the people sent a shout, âThough false men lie, And brave men die, God send us traitors more!â
